author: sameelaughs
content: Rutilius Rufus was exiled to Asia because he was wrongly convicted in the extortion court, despite trying to stop extortion. At his place of exile, in Smyrna, he lived as an honoured citizen among the provincials he was alleged to have oppressed, was heavily praised by Vellius Paterculus, and visited by Cicero. Sulla asked him to come back, but Rutilius Rufus said he didn't want to leave his 'exile'.

content:
A torc was a tight metal neck ring worn as an accessory by Scythian, Illyrians, Thracians, Celts, and more. The Dying Gaul statue has a torc on his neck.
Titus Manlius Torquatus Imperiosus earned the name 'Torquatus' because he defeated a Giant GaulTMÔ∏è at the Battle of Anio River and took his torc.

author: fabulapalliata
content: T. S. Eliot's *The Waste Land* mentions many cool things from mythology (and history!) in metaphor, such as the Battle of Mylae, Tiresias, and, impactfully, Philomela and Tereus. There's also lots of cool references to *Hamlet*, especially the character of Ophelia. Sincerely, your local T. S. Eliot lover
